conclusion: Ampere force is given by the formula F = BIL sinθ, where B is the magnetic field strength, I is the current, L is the length of the wire, and θ is the angle between the wire and the magnetic field.
A straight wire is bent into a V-shape with equal side lengths and an included angle of 60 degrees. It is placed in a uniform magnetic field perpendicular to the plane of the wire.

premise: The wire is in the shape of a V with an included angle of 60 degrees.
conclusion: Each arm of the V makes an angle of 30 degrees with the vertical.

premise: The included angle is 60 degrees and both arms are equal.
conclusion: Each arm makes an angle of 15 degrees with the vertical.

premise: The V-shape has an included angle of 60 degrees.
conclusion: The angle between the two arms is 60 degrees.

premise: The bisector is vertical and the included angle is 60 degrees.
conclusion: Each arm is at 30 degrees from the vertical.

premise: The wire is in a plane and the magnetic field is perpendicular to that plane.
conclusion: The angle between each arm of the wire and the magnetic field is 30 degrees.

premise: The plane of the wire is the XY-plane, and the magnetic field is along the Z-axis.
conclusion: Each arm of the V-shape makes an angle of 30 degrees with the vertical (Z-axis).

premise: The effective length of the wire in the magnetic field is 2l sin 30° = l.
conclusion: The magnitude of the Ampere force is F = BI × 2l sin 30° = BIl.
